questions.question: What is dynamic range in photography?
options: The range of focal lengths your lens can zoom
The range between the darkest and brightest tones a camera can capture at once
The color gamut of the sensor
questions.reviewHint: DR = dark-to-bright span the camera can record without losing detail.

questions.question: Which scene usually has high dynamic range (hard to expose in one shot)?
options: Overcast sky and evenly lit subject
Bright sky with a dark foreground at sunset
questions.reviewHint: Bright sky + dark land = big brightness gap → high DR.

questions.question: On the histogram, blown highlights are indicated by:
options: A tall spike in the center
Data piled up hard against the right edge
Data piled up hard against the left edge
questions.reviewHint: Right edge = highlight clipping; left edge = shadow clipping.

questions.question: You're losing detail in the bright sky. Easiest first step?
questions.reviewHint: Go brighter ( +EV ) to lift shadows, darker ( −EV ) to save highlights.

questions.question: For maximum editing flexibility with dynamic range, shoot:
questions.reviewHint: RAW files retain more highlight/shadow detail.

questions.question: Which typically reduces a camera's usable dynamic range?
options: Stopping down from f/4 to f/8
Raising ISO far above base ISO
questions.reviewHint: Higher ISO usually lowers DR (less highlight headroom, more noise).

questions.question: When is HDR / exposure bracketing most helpful?
options: Static scenes with bright sky + dark foreground
questions.reviewHint: HDR works best when little moves between frames.

questions.question: Outdoor backlit portrait (bright sky behind, face in shade) without bracketing—what helps keep both usable?
options: Spot meter the sky and keep it dark
Expose a bit for the highlights (−EV) and add fill (flash/reflector), or lift shadows later

questions.question: A graduated ND filter is most useful when:
options: The whole scene is uniformly dark
The sky is much brighter than the land
questions.reviewHint: Grad ND darkens the sky so exposure fits the camera's DR.

questions.question: Expose To The Right (ETTR) means:
options: Overexpose until the image looks white
Place the histogram as far right as possible without clipping
questions.reviewHint: ETTR aims for brighter (noise-cleaner) exposure without blowing highlights.

questions.question: Which statement is most accurate about dynamic range vs. contrast?
options: Contrast is how tones are distributed/appear; DR is the camera's capture limits
Higher contrast always means higher DR
DR is only about color saturation

questions.question: In post-processing of a RAW file with bright clouds just below clipping, which control is most helpful?
questions.reviewHint: Highlights slider helps recover near-clipped bright areas.
